column2: The ghoul-like fever was not to be braved with impunity, and baulked of its prey.
column3: The ghoul like fever was not to be braved with impunity, and baulked of its prey.

column2: The board, not so formidable as she had imagined, had inquired into her case; and, instead of sending her to Stoke Claypole, her husband's Buckinghamshire parish, as she had dreaded, had agreed to pay her rent.
column3: The board, not so formidable as she had imagined, had inquired into her case; and, instead of sending her to Stoke Claypole, her husband's Buckinghamshire parish, as she had dreaded, had agreed to pay her rent.

column2: So food for four mouths was all she was now required to find; only for three she would have said; for herself and the unweaned child were but reckoned as one in her calculation.
column3: So food for four mouths was all she was now required to find; only for three she would have said; for herself and the unweaned child were but reckoned as one in her calculation.

column2: Her plan of living was so far arranged, when she heard, with keen sorrow, that Wilson's twin lads were ill of the fever.
column3: Her plan of living was so far arranged, when she heard, with keen sorrow, that Wilson's twin lads were ill of the fever.

column2: They were like many a pair of twins, and seemed to have but one life divided between them.
column3: They were like many a pair of twins, and seemed to have but one life divided between them.

column2: But when the twins, after ailing many days, and caring little for their meat, fell sick on the same afternoon, with the same heavy stupor of suffering, the three hearts that loved them so, each felt, though none acknowledged to the other, that they had little chance for life.
column3: But when the twins, after ailing many days, and caring little for their meat, fell sick on the same afternoon, with the same heavy stupor of suffering, the three hearts that loved them so, each felt, though none acknowledged to the other, that they had little chance for life.

column2: Over the child, which yet breathed, the father bent, watching anxiously for some ground of hope, where hope there was none.
column3: Over the child, which yet breathed, the father bent, watching anxiously for some ground of hope, where hope there was none.

column2: But earnest as the father was in watching the yet-living, he had eyes and ears for all that concerned the dead, and sprang gently up, and took his dead son on his hard couch in his arms with tender strength, and carried him upstairs as if afraid of wakening him.
column3: But earnest as the father was in watching the yet living, he had eyes and ears for all that concerned the dead, and sprang gently up, and took his dead son on his hard couch in his arms with tender strength, and carried him upstairs as if afraid of wakening him.

column2: We mun get him away from his mother.	We mun get him away from his mother.
He cannot die while she's wishing him."
column3: He cannot die while she's wishing him."

column2: Alice and Mary stood by with eyes fixed on the poor child, whose struggles seemed to increase, till at last his mother said with a choking voice,
column3: Alice and Mary stood by with eyes fixed on the poor child, whose struggles seemed to increase, till at last his mother said with a choking voice,

column2: She bent down, and fondly, oh! with what passionate fondness, kissed her child, and then gave him up to Alice, who took him with tender care.
column3: She bent down, and fondly, oh! with what passionate fondness, kissed her child, and then gave him up to Alice, who took him with tender care.

column2: Nature's struggles were soon exhausted, and he breathed his little life away in peace.
column3: Nature's struggles were soon exhausted, and he breathed his little life away in peace.

column2: Again Alice laid out the dead, Mary helping with reverent fear.
column3: Again Alice laid out the dead, Mary helping with reverent fear.

column2: Where is he? asked Mary.
column3: Where is he? asked Mary.

column2: But just now he hardly saw her; he went straight up to Alice, and asked how the little chaps were.
column3: But just now he hardly saw her; he went straight up to Alice, and asked how the little chaps were.

column2: He had stolen out during the half-hour allowed at the works for tea, to buy them an orange or two, which now puffed out his jacket-pocket.
column3: He had stolen out during the half hour allowed at the works for tea, to buy them an orange or two, which now puffed out his jacket pocket.

column2: They're both gone, said she.
column3: They're both gone, said she.

column2: Dead!
column3: Dead!

column2: They took worse about two o'clock.
column3: They took worse about two o'clock.

column2: Jem went to the cupboard, and quietly extricated from his pocket the oranges he had bought.
column3: Jem went to the cupboard, and quietly extricated from his pocket the oranges he had bought.

column2: They cried afresh in company.
column3: They cried afresh in company.

column2: Mary's heart melted within her as she witnessed Jem's sorrow, and she stepped gently up to the corner where he stood, with his back turned to them, and putting her hand softly on his arm, said,
column3: Mary's heart melted within her as she witnessed Jem's sorrow, and she stepped gently up to the corner where he stood, with his back turned to them, and putting her hand softly on his arm, said,

column2: Oh, Jem, don't give way so; I cannot bear to see you.
column3: Oh, Jem, don't give way so; I cannot bear to see you.

column2: Jem felt a strange leap of joy in his heart, and knew the power she had of comforting him.
column3: Jem felt a strange leap of joy in his heart, and knew the power she had of comforting him.

column2: Don't, Jem, please don't, whispered she again, believing that his silence was only another form of grief.
column3: Don't, Jem, please don't, whispered she again, believing that his silence was only another form of grief.

column2: He could not contain himself.
column3: He could not contain himself.

column2: But as he turned to catch a look at her sweet face, he saw that it expressed unfeigned distress, almost amounting to vexation; a dread of him, that he thought was almost repugnance.
column3: But as he turned to catch a look at her sweet face, he saw that it expressed unfeigned distress, almost amounting to vexation; a dread of him, that he thought was almost repugnance.

column2: Partly to relieve her from his presence, and partly from natural desire, and partly, perhaps, from a penitent wish to share to the utmost his parents' sorrow, he soon went up-stairs to the chamber of death.
column3: Partly to relieve her from his presence, and partly from natural desire, and partly, perhaps, from a penitent wish to share to the utmost his parents' sorrow, he soon went up stairs to the chamber of death.

column2: Mary mechanically helped Alice in all the duties she performed through the remainder of that long night, but she did not see Jem again.
column3: Mary mechanically helped Alice in all the duties she performed through the remainder of that long night, but she did not see Jem again.

column2: So leaving kind messages to George and Jane Wilson, and hesitating whether she might dare to send a few kind words to Jem, and deciding that she had better not, she stepped out into the bright morning light, so fresh a contrast to the darkened room where death had been.
column3: So leaving kind messages to George and Jane Wilson, and hesitating whether she might dare to send a few kind words to Jem, and deciding that she had better not, she stepped out into the bright morning light, so fresh a contrast to the darkened room where death had been.

column2: Mary lay down on her bed in her clothes; and whether it was this, or the broad daylight that poured in through the sky-window, or whether it was over-excitement, it was long before she could catch a wink of sleep.
column3: Mary lay down on her bed in her clothes; and whether it was this, or the broad daylight that poured in through the sky window, or whether it was over excitement, it was long before she could catch a wink of sleep.

column2: Her thoughts ran on Jem's manner and words; not but what she had known the tale they told for many a day; but still she wished he had not put it so plainly.
column3: Her thoughts ran on Jem's manner and words; not but what she had known the tale they told for many a day; but still she wished he had not put it so plainly.

column2: I think I cannot go right, for I either check myself till I'm downright cross to him, or else I speak just natural, and that's too kind and tender by half.
column3: I think I cannot go right, for I either check myself till I'm downright cross to him, or else I speak just natural, and that's too kind and tender by half.

column2: And I'm as good as engaged to be married to another; and another far handsomer than Jem; only I think I like Jem's face best for all that; liking's liking, and there's no help for it.
column3: And I'm as good as engaged to be married to another; and another far handsomer than Jem; only I think I like Jem's face best for all that; liking's liking, and there's no help for it.

column2: Well, when I'm Mrs. Harry Carson, may happen I can put some good fortune in Jem's way.
column3: Well, when I'm mrs Harry Carson, may happen I can put some good fortune in Jem's way.

column2: How she would surround him with every comfort she could devise (of course, he was to live with them), till he should acknowledge riches to be very pleasant things, and bless his lady-daughter!
column3: How she would surround him with every comfort she could devise (of course, he was to live with them), till he should acknowledge riches to be very pleasant things, and bless his lady daughter!
